message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest myasthenia gravis, which is associated with thymic hyperplasia or a thymoma. An increasing response on repeated nerve stimulation suggests Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome, which is caused by antibodies directed against presynaptic P/Q calcium channels. A neoplasm of lung neuroendocrine cells refers to small cell lung cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and response to edrophonium suggest the patient has myasthenia gravis. Option B is correct as thymoma is frequently found in patients with myasthenia gravis. Option A is incorrect as repetitive nerve stimulation leads to a decremental response in myasthenia gravis. Option C is incorrect as it describes small cell lung cancer, which is associated with Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome. Option D is incorrect as it describes Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome, which is caused by antibodies directed against presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms of ptosis and blurry vision that worsen throughout the day, as well as response to edrophonium, are consistent with myasthenia gravis. Option B is correct as myasthenia gravis can be associated with thymoma or hyperplasia of the thymus gland. Option A is incorrect as repeated nerve stimulation will actually lead to fatigue and worsening of symptoms in myasthenia gravis. Option C is incorrect as a neoplasm of lung neuroendocrine cells would suggest small cell lung cancer, which is associated with Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome rather than myasthenia gravis. Option D is incorrect as antibodies against presynaptic P/Q calcium channels are associated with Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome rather than myasthenia gravis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of ptosis that worsens throughout the day and improves with edrophonium are indicative of myasthenia gravis, which is associated with a benign proliferation of epithelial cells of the thymus. An increasing response on nerve stimulation is seen in Lambert-Eaton syndrome, not myasthenia gravis. Neoplasms of lung neuroendocrine cells cause paraneoplastic syndromes, not myasthenia gravis. Antibodies directed against presynaptic P/Q calcium channels cause Lambert-Eaton syndrome, not myasthenia gravis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of bilateral ptosis that worsens throughout the day and improves with edrophonium suggests myasthenia gravis. Myasthenia gravis is often associated with a benign proliferation of epithelial cells of the thymus (option B). An increasing response on repeated nerve stimulation is seen in Lambert-Eaton syndrome, which is caused by antibodies directed against presynaptic P/Q calcium channels (option D). A neoplasm of lung neuroendocrine cells is associated with paraneoplastic syndromes, which can also cause visual symptoms, but the presentation does not fit with this option.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Myasthenia Gravis (MG). Administering edrophonium leads to an improvement in her symptoms, which is characteristic of MG. Choice (A) is incorrect because an increasing response will not be seen on repeated nerve stimulation in patients with MG. Choice (C) is incorrect because it describes Small Cell Lung Cancer, which may harbor a paraneoplastic syndrome called Lambert-Eaton syndrome. Choice (D) is incorrect because it describes the pathophysiology of Lambert-Eaton syndrome, not MG. Therefore, the correct answer is (B), which describes the association of MG with thymic hyperplasia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of myasthenia gravis, which is associated with a benign proliferation of epithelial cells of the thymus. Option A is incorrect as myasthenia gravis usually shows a decremental response on repeated nerve stimulation. Option C refers to small cell lung cancer, which can cause Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome, not myasthenia gravis. Option D refers to Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome, which is caused by antibodies directed against presynaptic P/Q calcium channels, not myasthenia gravis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of myasthenia gravis, which is associated with a benign epithelial cell proliferation of the thymus in approximately 75% of cases. A repeated nerve stimulation test would not show increasing response in myasthenia gravis. Neoplasms of lung neuroendocrine cells can cause Lambert-Eaton syndrome, which also involves muscle weakness but is not associated with ptosis. Antibodies against presynaptic P/Q calcium channels are associated with Lambert-Eaton syndrome, not myasthenia gravis. The immediate improvement after administering edrophonium is consistent with myasthenia gravis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and exam findings suggest myasthenia gravis. Administering edrophonium causing an immediate improvement in symptoms confirms this diagnosis. Among the options, only myasthenia gravis is associated with a benign proliferation of epithelial cells of the thymus, which can be seen in up to 70% of patients. The other options are associated with different conditions such as Lambert-Eaton syndrome or paraneoplastic syndromes. An increasing response on repeated nerve stimulation would be seen in Lambert-Eaton syndrome, not myasthenia gravis. Antibodies against presynaptic P/Q calcium channels are seen in the Lambert-Eaton syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with ptosis and blurry vision, which are classic symptoms of myasthenia gravis. The improvement with edrophonium confirms the diagnosis. Option (A) is false because repetitive nerve stimulation would show a decremental response in myasthenia gravis. Option (C) is false because it describes small cell lung cancer, which is associated with Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome, not myasthenia gravis. Option (D) is false because it describes Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome, not myasthenia gravis. Myasthenia gravis is commonly associated with thymoma, a benign proliferation of epithelial cells of the thymus.
